awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Run-In and Superlubricity of Diamond-Like Carbon Coatings from a Tribochemical Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Smartphone screens are an impressive example of how new technologies often rely on surface engineering, such as the ability to create durable, hard and slippery surfaces. Many key economic sectors can benefit from minimized wear and friction of surfaces, including the automotive, medical device, computer component and defense sectors, so that this research directly and positively impacts the economic welfare and national security of the United States. Recently, a hard surface coating known as diamond-like carbon (DLC) has been found to achieve an extreme level of slipperiness called "superlubricity". This desirable property is, however, very sensitive to environmental conditions such as the amount of water or hydrogen in the surrounding atmosphere. Sensitivity to environmental conditions limits the effectiveness of the coating for many potential applications. This collaborative research aims to understand the chemical reactions that govern superlubricity in DLC and to discover ways to extend its high performance to a wider range of conditions.  The collaborators at Penn State and St. Olaf College specialize in measuring friction using different state-of-the-art methods that complement each other. The broader impacts of this study extend to training the next generation of scientists in the United States by supporting student participation in the research. Educational activities will include outreach for underrepresented minority recruitment at Penn State and undergraduates at St. Olaf, instruction of undergraduates in friction-related physics at St. Olaf, instruction in DLC surface properties for a graduate course at Penn State, surface characterization tutorials in professional conferences, and student participation in international collaborations. 

Due to its amorphous nature, the carbon atoms in DLC have very broad distributions in bond length and angle. The covalent bonds in DLC are formed during the high-energy deposition process and cannot be relaxed or rearranged without annealing at extremely high temperatures. This means that the lengths and angles of many bonds in DLC deviate significantly from the minimum-energy structure of ideal sp2 and sp3 hybridization. Those bonds are weaker and more reactive compared to the bonds with parameters close to the ideal structures. Such broad distributions in bond parameters and reactivities are intrinsic parameters specific to each DLC coating and its deposition conditions. The main thesis of this study is that the presence of highly-distorted carbon-carbon bonds facilitates a mechanochemically-induced polymorphic transition to graphitic domains at the shearing interface. Under this hypothesis, the run-in process can be attributed to the shear-induced mechanochemical transformation of the distorted carbon networks to graphitic (or graphene-like) domains. The transformation process will also be affected by reactions with molecules impinging from the gas phase. These surface reactions with surrounding gas molecules are extrinsic parameters affecting the run-in and superlubricity of DLC. A mechanically-assisted thermal activation (Arrhenius-type) model will be combined with structural characterization to study how the intrinsic and extrinsic parameters facilitate or hamper the shear-induced mechanochemical transformation of the DLC interface to graphitic domains with ultra-low shear resistance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogenated diamond-like carbon (H-DLC), which is a form of amorphous carbon produced via plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition process, is hard to resist wear and can exhibit an ultra-low friction behavior in oxygen-free and water-free environments. The super-lubricity is always observed after a short period of high friction, which is called a ‘run-in’ process. Although a few electron micrography studies have shown the presence of ‘graphitic’ structures at the H-DLC surface after the run-in process, the exact chemical and physical natures of this graphic layer have been elusive, which was the main focus of this project. This study tested the hypothesis that the run-in process can be viewed as the shear-induced mechanochemical transformation of the amorphous carbon network with a great deal of distorted local structures to graphitic (or graphene-like) domains with low density of highly-reactive defect sites. To test this hypothesis, we have used microscopic Raman analysis to characterize the sp2/sp3 hybridization ratio, graphitic domain size, and hydrogen contents of the interfacial shear plane responsible for the friction measured. Since the probe depth of Raman spectroscopy is too deep to differentiate signal from the topmost layer (consisting of the shear plane) from signals from the bulk, we have analyzed the transfer film formed on the counter-surface. In that way, the carbon structure most relevant to the sliding interface could be analyzed without the interference from the bulk signal. Because the transfer film is formed under non-equilibrium condition, the surface structure and chemistry probed in air after the tribotest are highly responsive to the environmental condition during the tribotest.

Through these studies, we have found that in dry nitrogen, the super-lubricity is highly sensitive to the hydrogen (H) content in the H-DLC film, and its effect is not only the passivation of reactive sites, but also the alteration of the degree of graphitization. That explained why the film with 30% H-content gives high friction (coefficient of friction COF >0.7), while the film with 40% H-content exhibits super-lubricity (COF  £0.01).  From the environment dependence study, it was found that the presence of reducing elements (such as H2) in the gas phase can induce super-lubricity of the low H-content film through in-situ reactions with the reactive sites exposed during the friction; this also the degree of graphitization almost identical with the one observed for the super-lubricious 40% H-content film. The presence of oxidizing agents (such as O2 and H2O) prevents the formation of such super-lubricious structure due to oxidation of reactive sites. The presence of oxygen in the environment induces a carbon structure that easily wears off upon friction. The presence of water induces the formation of physisorbed water layer; since the shear takes place in the adsorbed water layer, the shear-induced graphitization does not occur readily.

Most literatures reporting the super-lubricity of H-DLC were done with macroscopic friction tests; it is extremely rare to find the report showing the super-lubricity of H-DLC in nano-scale friction tests although there are a plethora of nanoscale friction studies on various aspects of tribology. In collaboration with Brian Borovsky and his undergraduate students at St.Olaf College, we have tested if the super-lubricity can be observed in the microscale test. It was possible to induce super-lubricity in the microscale if a proper run-in process was incorporated into the test procedure. But, we have not demonstrated the super-lubricity of the same H-DLC film in the nanoscale testing with atomic force microscopy. Using Raman spectroscopy and microscopic imaging, we have found that the nanoscale contact is not big enough to keep the super-lubricious transfer film during the sliding since the contact area is so small. Thus, even if the super-lubricious structure is formed (which is likely because the shear stress is much larger at the nanoscale compared to the micro and macroscales), it can be easily slipped off the contact area. In other words, it means that the lack of super-lubricity at the nanoscale is not an intrinsic property of H-DLC, but the extrinsic property of the test condition.  

Through this project the Penn State team collaborated and guided the undergraduate students at St.Olaf College. A lot of surface characterization data obtained in this study (especially, XPS and Raman analysis results) were used in the graduate-level surface characterization class. The graduate student has been trained with multi-disciplinary skillsets connecting chemical engineering with mechanical engineering. He also gained experiences in collaboration with a computational group at University of Californina, Merced, and industrial researchers at Morgan Advanced Materials. Considering the rarity of students with such backgrounds, it is very likely that he will bring diversity into the tribology and lubrication engineering communities, which are important disciplines for advanced manufacturing. He will be taking an internship in a tribology group at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in the next semester.
